title: On voting day, Republicans and Democrats can agree on one thing – keep our primary first
authors: Don Babwin, Herb Mccann -, David Sharp -, Alyssa Dandrea -, Aritz Parra -
content:

The lead-up to Tuesday ’ s Election Day was an ugly time in America .
The impeachment proceedings cemented the hard feelings between the two parties , seemingly spoiling any chance that the Republicans and Democrats will agree on much going forward .
But on Election Day , that changed , at least at Three Rivers School in Pembroke . That ’ s where residents voted , members of both parties , and that ’ s where they essentially said the same thing to me when asked if it ’ s time our high-profile spot in the voting process moved on .
Hands off our first-in-the-nation primary , they said . It belongs to us .
“ We should be keeping it , ” said Mike Murphy , a children ’ s music teacher . “ We know people are complaining . They say we are not diverse enough . ”
Rep. Diane Schuett cited our Congressional Delegation , which includes three women and a gay man .
“ I travel a lot , and people say , ‘ How come you have ( the first primary ) , ’ ” Schuett said . “ Well , I say ‘ Because we were smart enough to institute it . ’ ”
Did you catch it ? The word “ We , ” coming from both Murphy and Schuett . Murphy loved President Donald Trump . Schuett is a Democrat .
Finally , harmony , an olive branch , a treaty . On Tuesday , anyway , the months of political rancor melted away as Granite Staters coalesced around our special day . The one that makes other states envious .
“ I get to talk to the candidates , ” said Bernie Fournier , standing in front of the school with a three-tier sign promoting Bernie Sanders . “ I can ask them questions and see them answer without a script , what they think and what they feel . ”
He continued : “ Where else can you get first-hand information from the candidates . It ’ s one of the nice things about living in New Hampshire . Not everybody in other states likes that , but I do . ”
New Hampshire ’ s place in the voting order could be tied to the corn stalks in Iowa , where it took forever last week to tabulate the votes from their Caucus and announce the winners . Something about a malfunctioning app .
Pete Buttigieg and Bernie Sanders led the pack , but the jokes on late-night TV were relentless , leaving the Democratic Party and officials in Iowa with egg on their face . As it was , Iowa had already heard about its shortcomings , the same stuff we hear .
New Hampshire , like Iowa , is too white , too old , too rural , too isolated .
New Hampshire is also the perfect state for canvasing , our winters notwithstanding . The candidates could never buzz around a state like California .
Here , it ’ s called retail politics , and there ’ s nothing quite like it , anywhere in the country .
“ Being a smaller state , candidates can go all over the place , ” Fournier told me . “ You talk to everybody . You go and shake the hand of somebody . You knock on doors . ”
Earl Phair would be irked if the primary was taken from us . He admitted , however , that he also grew tired of the various campaigns that had bombarded him with information , sometimes with a ring , other times with a knock , still other times with the interruption of his favorite TV show .
“ We should definitely keep ( the primary ) , ” Phair said . “ But I think they ought to do away with all the commercials . It drives me nuts , and we don ’ t answer the phone . ”
While acknowledging that New Hampshire is home to few minorities , Sarah Carboneau said we ’ ve earned our place at the top of the primary list through tireless research and tough questioning .
“ I know there are a lot of people who think that we shouldn ’ t have it , ” Carboneau said . “ They think we need more diverse people to cast their votes . But New Hampshire has had it for so long , and we ’ re well-versed and educated about it , and I think we take it really seriously . ”
We do . It ’ s a day for the two parties , the voters in New Hampshire , to finally agree on something . Party affiliation didn ’ t matter . Not on Tuesday at Three Rivers School .
Reality is set to return , though , right after the election . The arguing , the pettiness , the politics .
It ’ s Democrats against President Donald Trump , all over again . The interpretation of the word “ truth , ” is so far apart within both camps as to be laughable .
These days , Republicans insist that the United States has never been better . The “ MAGA ” on those red hats no longer needs to be spelled out . We know what it means .
Democrats ? The clock is ticking on the apocalypse , so you ’ d better switch to solar electricity , fast .
Thankfully , then came Election Day . New Hampshire citizens on both sides of the aisle agreed on something , agreed to a ceasefire .
“ I think Americans like the way things run , ” Murphy said . “ I don ’ t think we see any reason to change it . ”
